review: I've never owned a similar device previously, so I don't have anything to compare it to, but...  I've found the advertising to be true; It IS easy to set up.  it DID recognize my WiFi instantly.  The voice search IS amazingly accurate.I originally looked at Chromecast but was dismayed to see that I needed a laptop or pad, or some internet device to "cast" the service to my TV.  I was drawn to Fire by the ad for the Fire Stick, but I liked the idea that the Fire TV box had the voice search, and more processing power.  Besides; at 4" square, it's extremely portable anyway, and totally inconspicuous.  After bundling it with Prime, it barely cost any more than the stick.I live in a rural area and have minimal broadband speed (equivalent to 3G), but most things I've watched have been totally seamless.  While viewing through the apps, like ESPN (which doesn't give you much, by way) and History, there were some brief stalls on occasion, but I'm sure a better internet connection would alleviate that.I did have one weird experience on the second day I had it.  I turned it on, along with the TV, but it just sat there with a black screen.  I thought it maybe took a while to download something, like when satellite or broadcast TV downloads a new program guide, but after 3 or 4 minutes, I realized nothing was happening.  I unplugged the power, plugged it back in, and everything was fine.  In the week since then I haven't had that happen again, so I hope it's not an issue.On a related side-note; Prime, which I bundled with Fire TV for a discount, is only "okay."  Yes, there's a lot of free stuff, but most of the free stuff is not what I really want to watch.  The movies and shows I was hoping for are mostly extra - usually around $1.99 to $2.99 each.
